bug.short_desc: "Exclude methods with neglible base time" filter not working properly

long_desc.thetext:
I am testing the TPTP 4.3 i3 200611070100 driver and find that the "Exclude methods with neglible base time" filter does not show correct results. For example, I created the following filter:
Highest 7 calls "Exclude get/set/is methods" is checked "Exclude methods with neglible base time" is not checked.
When I apply this filter in the Class Level Execution Statistics View, the top 7 classes in terms of number of calls is displayed.
When I check "Exclude methods with neglible base time" and apply the filter again, a class with a negligible base time (0.005804) is shown but a class with a larger base time (0.0188874) and higher number of calls is not shown. I'll attach screen shots that show this. Similar behaviour occurs when applying the filter to the Method level Execution Statistics view and it is a method in the same class as above that is not shown when it should be.

Created an attachment (id=53785) Class level view with "Exclude methods with neglible base time" not checked
This shows the ConsolePrintStream class that should be shown with "Exclude methods with neglible base time" is checked.

Created an attachment (id=53787) Class level view when "Exclude methods with neglible base time" is checked
ConsolePrintStream is not shown when it should be.

Created an attachment (id=53831) Here's the proposed fix
This patch should fix the problem

Dave Can you test with the attached fix and let me know if this resolves the issue.
Thanks
I looked at this issue and given the current stage - retargetting the same to 4.4
Ruslan - Alexander had a patch attached but did not make a cut since the check ins were closed in 4.3. Please see if the patch is valid and can be applied. Address this after your P1 defects are done

Guru,
the patch seems to be valid and can be applied without conflicts. It affect following projects: org.eclipse.tptp.platform.common.ui org.eclipse.hyades.trace.views
Eugene, Can you review the patch and apply them. They are to be committed in the Trace and Platform components.
Patch does not fix the problem. I will atttach screen shot and explain.

(In reply to comment #9) Never mind my last comment. I had 'Exclude get/set/is method' checked which leads to a wrong conclusion.
I retest again and the patch looks good. I also review the patch and it looks good to me.
Guru, please go ahead with the approval request.

Eugene, Approved to check in. Please check in the fix
Thanks
Patch is submitted.

bug.short_desc: Generating reports on JUnit test suites without any execution history files will create erroneous results

long_desc.thetext:
To reproduce:
1) Create a JUnit test suite with a test case 2) Launch the test suite 3) Right click the JUnit test suite and select report 4) Select "HTML Tabular Test Report (BIRT)" 5) Specify a time window so that the execution history file is not picked up 6) Click finish
The snapshot attached is the result that I got. This defect is JUnit specific. It works fine for Manual/AGR test suites.
Created an attachment (id=53782) report snapshot
This only occurs if the testsuite is a junit testsuite and if no execution histories are found.

Fix is in the report template file.
Applied Patch.
Reporter: Please verify and close in preparation for shutting down the TPTP 4.4 release. Thanks.
Closing

bug.short_desc: Profiler does not collect Cumulative CPU Time on linuxPPC64

long_desc.thetext:
Platform: Linuxppc64 Build: TPTP-4.3.0-200611070100 RAC jvm: java version "1.5.0" Java(TM) 2 Runtime Environment, Standard Edition (build pxp64dev-20061002a (SR3) ) IBM J9 VM (build 2.3, J2RE 1.5.0 IBM J9 2.3 Linux ppc64-64 j9vmxp6423-20061001 (JIT enabled) J9VM - 20060915_08260_BHdSMr JIT - 20060908_1811_r8 GC - 20060906_AA) JCL - 20061002
1. Install rac 2. Install TPTP workbench 3. Enable "Collect method CPU time information" in the profile configurations 4. Profile a simple java class 5. Examine the Cumulative CPU Time column and you will notice that the times are set to 0.0 Seconds.
When you write the profiling data to a file, the Cumlative CPU time is recorded as 0.0. It seems as if the piAgent is returning the wrong information.

I am retargeting this to 4.4 (but setting priority at 2). The rationale is that we are attempting to close 4.3 today and this is of major and not critical severity.
I believe it is only major severity because it is restricted to a single platform only and to a more recent feature of profiling (CPU time measurement) which has had restrictions from the beginning on certain platforms (eg: Solaris).
Retarget to future due to resource limitation.

Note that I won't have much time to put towards this until 1.0 is out, and it may be best for you to wait until the week of Dec. 4th to do major work because we'll be giving the APIs a revision next week.
Can someone explain to me why open source projects like one in this bug description require authorization?

It requires authorization only if you wish to modify source code. Otherwise everything else (wiki, documents) should be open for reading and editing as anonymous. You can view/read the source code (waiting for stabilization of Mylar API) by using user/password anonymous/anon. I do not want to entirely open the source code to anybody, some good sould can delete or maliciously modify files (have experience with it with othe open source project). If you still problem to access parts of the project as anonymous, let me know. You can now join the project as Customer automatically without my approval. bug.short_desc: Renaming JSP causes content assist to fail

long_desc.thetext:
A few times I've had content assist fail or display suggestions out of context (e.g. a list of classes where I would expect a list of methods). The common theme seems to be that I have recently renamed the file. For example:
Create a file 'A.jsp' containing:
<% Integer. %>
Locating the cursor after the dot and pressing Ctrl-SPACE shows content assist as expected.
Rename the JSP as 'B.jsp'.
Repeat the above exercise. Content assist now fails and shows 'Java Content Assist is not available for the current cursor location' in the status bar.
Close the editor and reopen it. Content assist now works as expected.

When I import the C data and profile a Java application into the same monitor, select the monitor, and select one application context or the other, the Execution statistics view does not refresh to show the newly selected context. - For example, when I imported the C data into the monitor and then profiled a Java application then I cannot show the Execution Statistics (Execution Statistics tab) in the Java application context. - When I profiled the Java application first and then imported the C data I cannot show the Execution Statistics tab in the C application context.
This may related to bug 161335
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 161335 ***

bug.short_desc: Make fan router work with ShortestPathConnectionRouter

long_desc.thetext: Fan and SPC routers can't be used in conjunction because the SPCR invalidates certain connections in its route method. To prevent that from adversely affecting the router, it has an ignoreInvalidate field. When you use the two routers together, the fanned connections keep jumping around (their index changes), because of the invalidation happening in the route() method. What we need is for Automatic/Fan router to have the same ignoreInvalidate field which is set to true before next.route() is invoked, and set to false after it's done.

bug.short_desc: Consolidate palette preferences

long_desc.thetext:
Currently, there are the PaletteViewerPreferences which are set in a PreferenceStore and the FlyoutPreferences which use org.eclipse.core.runtime.Preferences. They could be unified.
While the FlyoutPreferences are live (changing a property in one editor, immediately updates all other open editors), the PaletteViewerPreferences are not.
Also, there is no easy way to set the defaults for these preferences.
Note that I'm suggesting an API change here, and so this wouldn't really be for a point release.

bug.short_desc: [api] Removing the "Default System Type" combo from the RSE Preference page

long_desc.thetext:
New Connection wizard Select System Type page no longer honors default system type settings in preferences for Remote Systems.
In preference->Remote Systems, user can specify the "Default System Type" settings. And in the old New Connection wizard (with list of system types displayed instead of drop down), the default stystem type will be selected as default when user try to create a new connection. But in the new "Select System Type" page of the wizard, the first system type is always selected and the default system type setting is ignored.

Good catch!
My personal feeling is, though, that a better solution would be to simply remember the previous selection in the New Connection Wizard. Most Eclipse "New" wizards work that way -- e.g. New Project.
This seems to be a more natural approach to me, and it would perhaps allow us to get rid of the "Default System Type" Preference page. Yu-Fen, if you agree please change the Summary of this bug to "New Connection Wizard should remember previous selection".

I'd prefer to keep the existing "Default System Type" functionality. Since vendors can plugin their own "System Type" thru rse extensions, when creating a new connection, usually they expect their user to be using their own "System Type" and without the "Default System Type" preference, there is no way for vendor's plugin code to set the default settings of system type for their user.

I'm still not so convinced about the "default system type" concept.
* You can only select a single default system type. What if a vendor (like us) contributes multiple system types? - I think that eventually - RSE should support grouping system types by category, just like the Eclipse New Project Wizard does. Then, there would be a category "Default", another one "Windriver", a third one "Montavista". Users would find the right system type more easily. - RSE should use Eclipse Capabilities to allow vendors to hide system types that their users are not expected to see by default.
* Vendors cannot foresee what users want to do. It's more user-friendly to remember the previous decision - and it's more consistent with what Eclipse does.
Sorting out the right thing will take until after 1.0.1. If you think you'll need the "default system type" concept in RSE 1.0.1 for your product, please comment here again.

For TM 2.0M5, the new connection wizard has been rewritten to make use of the Eclipse Platform WizardSelectionPage. The wizard does now support Categories for system types, and the default selection is always the one that was selected previously (just like in the Eclipse New Project Wizard).
I think that this solution is the right one.
Since the "Default System Type" has no meaning any more, I think it should be removed from the Preference page. Please comment here on that plan.

+1 to remove it from the preferences.
Additional it should be checked where the SystemHostCombo is used in other places and if still make sense. The control is part of the system connection form but not utilized in there.

(In reply to comment #4) > For TM 2.0M5, the new connection wizard has been rewritten to make use of the > Eclipse Platform WizardSelectionPage. The wizard does now support Categories > for system types, and the default selection is always the one that was selected > previously (just like in the Eclipse New Project Wizard). > > I think that this solution is the right one. > > Since the "Default System Type" has no meaning any more, I think it should be > removed from the Preference page. Please comment here on that plan. >
A word of caution: This preference is used at least one place in the code in other than its use as the default for the former wizard. These need to be examined as to why they are used that way before we can remove the value from the preference page, the preference store, or preferences API.

Kushal (and Dave) - we just got bug 176483 which asks why the default of the default system type combo in preferences is empty. We've been considering removing the "default system type" combo before but you were unsure if this is possible.
Could you please investigate if it is possible to remove the "default system type" combo.
Since this would be an NLS changing thing, we should consider this for M6.
We agreed that the combo (and associated API in RSEPreferencesManager) should be removed for M6, but NL Strings should be kept for now.
Removed combo from preference page and associated preference constants and methods, but kept the NL strings. I have not noticed any problems.

This is an API change since RSEPreferencesManager.getSystemType() RSEPreferencesManager.setSystemType() are also removed.
Migration guide for extenders: If your code uses these methods, consider a different way of choosing a default system type. For instance, the first of all registered types; or the type previously selected in a form.
Future versions of RSE will use Capabilities / Activities to allow limiting the list of visible system types, such that extenders can tune their product by hiding system types that should not be shown. Right now, this can be done by deactivating a system type in the Preferences (through plugin_customization.ini).
Verified with I20070405-0600. Closing.

bug.short_desc: [Regression]The Data won't display as Date Time type after apply the style to it [0300]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: The Data won't display as Date Time type after apply the style to it.
Build number: 2.2.0.v20061113-0636
Steps to reproduce: 1. Drag a data from Palette to Layout, edit Expression as "new Date()". 2. Set date format to be "long date" in property editor. 3. Reset its format to Unformatted. 4. New a style with its date fomat "short date". 5. Apply the style to data element.
Expected result: The Data will display as short date.
Actual result: The Data still displays as Unformatted.
Error log: N/A

bug.short_desc: Add ODA Plug-in Project options to BIRT New Wizard Category

long_desc.thetext:
One of the extending BIRT options is to plug-in a custom data source to BIRT engine by providing an ODA-compliant data source driver. To implement the ODA extension points, one has to manually create corresponding plug-in projects manually. In DTP 1.0 release, the ODA framework now provides the new plug-in project template wizards to auto generate such plug-in projects (see Bugzilla 153999.
These two ODA project wizards are now available under the New Plug-in Project wizard's selection list. These options should also be added to BIRT new project wizard category, to make them more visible to the BIRT users.
Resolved.

bug.short_desc: Relative path issue about fragment and resource folder

Expected result: library in fragments can be included to the report with the right path(Fragment/templates/blank_library.rptlibrary)
Actual result: Warning that the library has been added to the report, and the library path in the warning message refer to resource folder/templates/blank_library.rptlibrary

This issue was discussed with UI team before. This is BIRT behavior. The priority of Resource Path is higher than the fragment. If resources (same pathes in resource path and fragment) are found in resource folder, BIRT will not search in the fragment again.

bug.short_desc: Task stays active after switching Eclipse workspace

long_desc.thetext: Task stays active after switching Eclipse workspace if both workspaces share the same .mylar folder. This is quite critical, because projects may disappear, or even worse, workspace has completely different projects under the same names. It probably would be better if active task saved info within workspace data.

I don't see how this is critical because it does not cause any damage to the Task List, contexts, or workspace, nor does it cause any crashes. Our entire architecture currently relies on the task activation data being stored in the task list, and this is where we get our history list as well as task timings. But I agree that we have a problem with the current story of sharing Mylar across workspaces (bug 130658). We need to wait for progress on Platform bug 154097 to figure out how to best resolve that.
The current work-around for this particular problem is to deactivate the active task before switching workspaces. Btw, could you mention more about your use case for switching workspaces?

You can't rely on users remembering things like deactivate tasks before doing something. It is critical because task view may not be in focus, so it is easy to screw task context after switching workspace.
Is there any problem in activating a task in a workspace with whose projects doesn't belong to it? i.e. there can be some type of "damage" to the context data?
Activating is not a problem. The problem is that context will be updated with unrelated events.

Our current model is that the active task is saved with the Task List, note with the workspace. The benefit of this is that importing task data or switching workspaces preserves the exact state that the task list was left in, including the active task. I believe that more users would complain if they imported or switched workspaces and their active task was not preserved. However, this is a design decision that could be revisited with more input.

In the old tree viewer like log view we were dislaying correlated events of an event. A solution would be to have the associated events tab displaying the associated events events as hypelinks, so that clicking on a hyperlink would select the corresponding event in the view. If the input to the log view is not a correlation container proxy then the actions should be either greyed out or rather not displayed.
Rough estimate 18h, including the displaying of associated CBE events in the Associated events tab.
I have removed the Show correlated... menu from the log view, which is not applicable.

bug.short_desc: fork requires aspectjtools.jar, which does not exist in AJDT

long_desc.thetext:

The iajc documentation says that you can specify the forkclasspath, but that still seems to require it to find aspectjtools.jar, as shown here:
unable to find aspectjtools to fork - tried C:\eclipse-rec\plugins\org.aspectj.weaver_1.5.2.20060629124300\aspectjweaver.jar
One solution would be to search for both aspectjtools.jar and aspectjweaver.jar. Another would be to make forkclasspath/forkclasspathref to accept a jar file.
Workaround of course is to use the full AspectJ install, but I wouldn't think I would need to do that.
Does this help: http://www.eclipse.org/ajdt/faq.php#q:ant?
Yes; I saw that FAQ entry earlier, but didn't notice that "fork" was set there. Thanks for the pointer.

bug.short_desc: Bugzilla Queries Give Wrong Results

long_desc.thetext:
I marked bug 164235 as RESOLVED WORKSFORME and if I look at that specific bug it really shows up as such but when I do a query, e.g.: https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/query.cgi?query_format=advanced&short_desc_type=allwordssubstr&short_desc=&classification=Eclipse&product=JDT&product=Platform&component=Text&long_desc_type=allwordssubstr&long_desc=&bug_file_loc_type=allwordssubstr&bug_file_loc=&status_whiteboard_type=allwordssubstr&status_whiteboard=&keywords_type=allwords&keywords=&bug_status=UNCONFIRMED&bug_status=NEW&bug_status=ASSIGNED&bug_status=REOPENED&emailtype1=substring&email1=&emailtype2=substring&email2=&bugidtype=include&bug_id=&votes=&chfieldfrom=&chfieldto=Now&chfieldvalue=&field0-0-0=noop&type0-0-0=noop&value0-0-0=
I get one single bug back (OK: it is bug 164235) BUT: the status is marked as REOPENED.
Similar, this query (restricts to REOPENED): https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/buglist.cgi?query_format=advanced&short_desc_type=allwordssubstr&short_desc=Copy%2Fpaste+&classification=Eclipse&product=JDT&product=Platform&component=Text&long_desc_type=allwordssubstr&long_desc=&bug_file_loc_type=allwordssubstr&bug_file_loc=&status_whiteboard_type=allwordssubstr&status_whiteboard=&keywords_type=allwords&keywords=&bug_status=REOPENED&emailtype1=substring&email1=&emailtype2=substring&email2=&bugidtype=include&bug_id=&votes=&chfieldfrom=1d&chfieldto=Now&chfieldvalue=&cmdtype=doit&order=Reuse+same+sort+as+last+time&field0-0-0=noop&type0-0-0=noop&value0-0-0= returns the bug as well but clicking on the bug and looking at the details reveals that the bug is resolved as WORKSFORME.
I marked this bug 'critical' because data integrity seems to be corrupted and I can no longer trust bugzilla.
NOTE: I waited for more than 10 minutes before I filed this bug and still no consistency between the query result and the bug.
Setting to blocker, since we e.g. cannot track inboxes any more using queries. Notification mails seem still to be fine.
AFAIK search goes to the replicated DB. Looks like it is out of sync again. :(

Yup, I (finally) resynced the slave over the weekend, but there's an index corruption for the search engine database on the slave, causing a blocking replication error. I've fixed the broken index, and the slave is catching up to the master right now.
This has been fixed.
>This has been fixed. Maybe the symptom but not the cause. Bugzilla queries are again out of sync.
Hrm. I've switched the queries back to the master until I can fix this.
>Hrm. I've switched the queries back to the master until I can fix this. That didn't help.

I had set queries to run on the slave yesterday for performance, and forgot to set it back to the master before I crashed for sleep. Apologies for this omission.
For some reason, the database slave just seems to like to stop replicating at night. It catches up fine, in the morning when I kick it, but this is just annoying.
This has been fixed, and both our databases have been performing well.

bug.short_desc: Signed features mistaken for plug-ins

long_desc.thetext:
Build: N-20061113
When you import features from the Target platform via the Feature Import wizard, the imported features do not recognized by PDE as features in the workspace.
Upon investigation, it turns out that this is due to the fact that the imported features are signed.
The META-INF/MANIFEST.MF folder in the imported feature causes confusion between the feature project structure and the plug-in project structure.
PDE is treating signed feature projects as plug-in projects.
Fixed by deleting the META-INF folder from the signed feature upon importing.

By "Change the column name of the file" do you mean change column name in the tsv file, or in data set editor?
Thanks. Lin

The change of the column name in flatfile datasource will cause a query error, because the changed column name is not in the query text any longer. In this case, instead of disabling both list and viewer, users can reselect the columns they need in the data set.
Right now, a data set with no columns can be saved.
resolved.

bug.short_desc: [content assist] Only call ICodeAssist.codeComplete(...) once

long_desc.thetext:
3.2 and 3.3 M3
JDT Text calls JDT Core code assist twice on each invocation. This happens because the final proposal list is computed by several different completion processors. Two of them (the "no type" and the "other proposals" processor) call ICodeAssist.codeComplete(...).
Note that this is not a bug but works as designed since we eat our own dog food by contributing the processor via extension point. We could however try to improve the performance by providing an internal processor that only combines the two and only calls JDT Core once.
Time permitting for 3.3.

I knew there was a bug for that but thought this was captured in the constructor proposal bug.
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of 162923 ***

bug.short_desc: [comments] DefaultCommentMapper should release scanner after use

long_desc.thetext:
20061114 If I understand right, the scanner used in the DefaultCommentMapper is only used when computing the ranges. All accesses to extended ranges are simple lookups in an array on no use of the scanner is required.
The scanner still holds the char[] of the soirtce content which can be quite big.
Fixed in method DefaultCommentMapper#initialize(CompilationUnit, Scanner). Released for 3.3 M4 in HEAD stream. No test case added.
Verified for 3.3M4 with I20061212-0010.

bug.short_desc: Selection of bar chart changes after selecting from 3D to 2D[0001]

long_desc.thetext:
Description: Selection of bar chart changes after selecting from 3D to 2D.
Build number: 2.2.0.v200611141013
Steps to reproduce: 1. Add a chart. 2. Select bar chart and select "stacked bar chart" first then change Dimension from 2D to 3D. 3. Then change back from 3D to 2D.
Expected result: The chart shown in Chart Preview is side-by-side bar chart.
Actual result: The chart shown in Chart Preview should be stacked bar chart.
Error log: N/A

ChartCacheManager caches the subtype info for each chart type. 3D bar charts haven't "stacked" subtype, so the subtype info is converted to "side-by-side". When switching back to 2D, the change is applied.
If we cache the dimension info as well, when switching from "2D" to "2D with depth", the selected subtype cannot be applied. It is also a shortcoming.
So after balancing the pros and cons, suggest to keep the original implementation.

Thanks for the patch. Unfortunately, it appears that the use of a filter defined in the CVS plug-in will cause the CVS plug-in to be loaded even if the user has no CVS projects in their workspace. It also appears that there is no way to avoid this with the current shape of the tabbed properties view contributions. I have logged bug 165160 requesting the ability to defined declarative filters.

bug.short_desc: Provide Mechanism to Expand Facet Category

long_desc.thetext: When adding facets to a Category, for display on the Facets page of the Dynamic Web Application project creation wizard, there is no way to expand the Category folder by default when the page is initially displayed. In some cases, the user doesn't see the facets listed in the category and accepts the defaults, which may or may not be their intention. It would be useful to be able to have the facet selection page display a category expanded when it's first made visible. Since this does not appear to be something that can be done programmatically, perhaps a new attribute of the category tag would be easier to provide this behavior.

In general, I am against giving such control to the facet author. If user's installation contains many facets from different vendors, then the result could be a real mess.
However, I am open to (a) adding API to allow categories to be programmatically expanded (would only be possible if you control the wizard such as by subclassing the dynamic web project wizard; would not affect standard wtp wizards), or (b) allowing productization profile to control which categories are expanded by default (would only be in affect if eclipse is launched from your installation with your product profile).
Are any of the above of value to your scenario?
I think it would be useful to allow expanding a category programmatically at the wizard level rather than the page level, as we would typically extend the dynamic web project wizard. Thanks!
I added setCategoryExpandedState() method to the FacetedProjectWizard class.
Actually, the class with the new method is ModifyFacetedProjectWizard, which is the base class for all faceted project wizards.
Released this work into the M6 code stream...

bug.short_desc: xsd:restrcition on xsd:complexType handled not properly

long_desc.thetext:
Following the discussion with Ed Merks in the newsgroup. http://www.eclipse.org/newsportal/article.php?id=20887&group=eclipse.tools.emf#20887 I am committing this bug as Ed Merks suggested a patch:
The problem is that have the following schema and I would like to generate a genmodel from it. <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <xsd:schema xmlns:javaee="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" xmlns:xsd="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema" attributeFormDefault="unqualified" elementFormDefault="qualified" targetNamespace="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" version="5"> <xsd:import namespace="http://www.w3.org/XML/1998/namespace" schemaLocation="http://www.w3.org/2001/xml.xsd" />
<xsd:complexType name="generic-booleanType"> <xsd:simpleContent> <xsd:restriction base="javaee:string"> <xsd:enumeration value="true" /> <xsd:enumeration value="false" /> <xsd:enumeration value="yes" /> <xsd:enumeration value="no" /> </xsd:restriction> </xsd:simpleContent> </xsd:complexType>
<xsd:complexType name="string"> <xsd:simpleContent> <xsd:extension base="xsd:token"> <xsd:attribute name="id" type="xsd:ID" /> </xsd:extension> </xsd:simpleContent> </xsd:complexType>
</xsd:schema>
Now when I generate the model from this schema the ecore looks like this: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <ecore:EPackage xmi:version="2.0" xmlns:xmi="http://www.omg.org/XMI" xmlns:xsi="http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema-instance" xmlns:ecore="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/Ecore" name="javaee" nsURI="http://java.sun.com/xml/ns/javaee" nsPrefix="javaee"> <eAnnotations source="http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2002/GenModel"> <details ... many details go here "/> </eAnnotations> <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="GenericBooleanType" eSuperTypes="#//String"> <eAnnotations source="http:///org/eclipse/emf/ecore/util/ExtendedMetaData"> <details key="name" value="generic-booleanType"/> <details key="kind" value="simple"/> </eAnnotations> </eClassifiers> <eClassifiers xsi:type="ecore:EClass" name="String"> <eAnnotations source="http:///org/eclipse/emf/ecore/util/ExtendedMetaData"> <details key="name" value="string"/> <details key="kind" value="simple"/> </eAnnotations> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="value" unique="false" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2003/XMLType#//Token"> <eAnnotations source="http:///org/eclipse/emf/ecore/util/ExtendedMetaData"> <details key="name" value=":0"/> <details key="kind" value="simple"/> </eAnnotations> </eStructuralFeatures> <eStructuralFeatures xsi:type="ecore:EAttribute" name="id" unique="false" eType="ecore:EDataType http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2003/XMLType#//ID" iD="true"> <eAnnotations source="http:///org/eclipse/emf/ecore/util/ExtendedMetaData"> <details key="kind" value="attribute"/> <details key="name" value="id"/> </eAnnotations> </eStructuralFeatures> </eClassifiers> </ecore:EPackage>
The problem is that the restriction on the value of generic-booleanType are not defined in the ecore file so the model does not know anything about those restrictions. I thought that there would be an EEnum or EDataType or event some eAnnotations on the GenericBooleanType.
The fix has been committed to CVS.
Works perfectly for me...
Actually, fixed in 2.3.0.I200611161558, not the maintenance branch.

bug.short_desc: index is set too late for resolving bindings?

long_desc.thetext:
Our driving force when building the DOM was to *NOT* do binding resolution during the parse phase. Resolving bindings is very time and memory consuming and we worked hard to minimize the amount of binding resolution that was done. Thus we purposely did not use bindings to resolve ambiguities, but introduced ambiguity nodes so that the ambiguities can be resolved as necessary after the parse. For operations like open declaration and content assist, we found that this saved us a lot.
I'm going to mark this as invalid to make sure we think long and hard about undoing this. Maybe the architecture has changed enough so that the savings aren't as big as they once were, but lets really make sure first.

sorry, I wasn't suggesting an architecture change :)
I was thinking that bindings are already sometimes resolved during parse - the stacktrace I'm seeing during parse where the index is unset is below. I believe if the index was set earlier, it could be used to resolve the requested binding. Maybe the error is that a binding resolution request is occuring at all (?)
Thread [Worker-4] (Suspended (breakpoint at line 766 in CPPSemantics)) CPPSemantics.postResolution(IBinding, CPPSemantics$LookupData) line: 766 CPPSemantics.resolveBinding(IASTName) line: 632 CPPVisitor.createBinding(IASTName) line: 167 CPPASTName.resolveBinding() line: 52 CPPASTAmbiguousStatement(CPPASTAmbiguity).accept(ASTVisitor) line: 68 CPPASTCompoundStatement.accept(ASTVisitor) line: 66 CPPASTFunctionDefinition.accept(ASTVisitor) line: 93 CPPASTTranslationUnit.accept(ASTVisitor) line: 556 GNUCPPSourceParser(AbstractGNUSourceCodeParser).resolveAmbiguities() line: 425 GNUCPPSourceParser(AbstractGNUSourceCodeParser).parse() line: 415 GPPLanguage.getASTTranslationUnit(CodeReader, IScannerInfo, ICodeReaderFactory, IIndex) line: 90 PDOMFastHandleDelta(PDOMFastIndexerJob).doParseTU(ITranslationUnit, IProgressMonitor) line: 103 PDOMFastHandleDelta(PDOMIndexerTask).parseTU(ITranslationUnit, IProgressMonitor) line: 135 PDOMFastHandleDelta(PDOMFastIndexerJob).parseTUs(List, List, IProgressMonitor) line: 281 PDOMFastHandleDelta.run(IProgressMonitor) line: 70 PDOMIndexerJob.run(IProgressMonitor) line: 67 Worker.run() line: 58

Technically, those amibiguities are resolved after the parse (but before the translation unit is returned). We are actually relying on some of those resolution attempts failing so that we can choose between ambiguities.
So setting the index before the parse would only affect the ambiguity resolution. Whether or not this is something that should be done would depend on the accuracy of the PDOM, since in this case, getting back a problem (nothing found) is better than getting back an incorrect binding that could cause us to keep the wrong AST branch.
In particular, I can already see a case where we may choose the wrong ambiguity branch if a pdom binding is returned.
I believe there are problems with the current integration of the index in CPPSemantics.postResolution, I will raise a separate bug for this.

That means that the index should be set in the translation unit before the execution of postResolution(). Because no name resolution will take place earlier than that it is also correct to set it right away. I will take care of the necessary changes.
I guess so... So much for my revisionist history :)

Fixed in 4.0 > 20061206.
The fix reduces the problem count for indexing firefox 2.0 from 485321 to 267636 problems.

bug.short_desc: Automatically refresh list of modules that are not projects

long_desc.thetext:
Following a thread in the new newsgroup titled "ModuleFactoryDelegate Question", it appears that if you develop modules for the Server API that are not projects, it is not possible to have their list automatically refreshed. This forces the user to restart the workspace before using the "Add/Remove" module wizard again.
In my project, I had to implement a custom Workbench listener that clears the cache of modules from my factory. I seems useful to have a similar mechanism built-in the framework.

This isn't a restriction on project modules. The factory just needs to call clearModuleCache() when the list is invalid, which will clear the list and cause it to be recreated.
Since this is currently working as designed I'm returning this bug. If there is something you think should be changed, please reopen with details.

When you create modules based on projects, you can subclass org.eclipse.wst.server.core.util.ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate which provides a static handleGlobalProjectChange() method.
This method iterates over all module factories and clears the module cache of instances of ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate only.
It would be nice to be able to benefit from the same mechanism from direct subclasses of ModuleFactoryDelegate.
Maybe ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate is intended to be used as a super class in all cases? If this is correct, then the Javadocs need to be updated as it says: "A helper class for defining a module factory that provides modules based on projects."

Modules don't need to be projects, so ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate is a helper class just for this specific (common) case. Users should also be free to create their own subclass of ModuleFactoryDelegate directly even when having project modules. In any case, users would have to implement their own 'uncaching' code when not subclassing from ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate.
Given this, the javadoc is not wrong. Is there some additional javadoc or description that would have helped you here, or is there something else you'd like to see changed?

Thanks for your clarifications. In my case, I indeed had to create my own subclass of ModuleFactoryDelegate as my modules are not projects. So, I'm changing this issue to an enhancement request instead.
The request is: could we move (and rename) the handleGlobalProjectChange() method from ProjectModuleFactoryDelegate to the ModuleFactoryDelegate in order to facilitate and optimize the detection of significant changes on the list of modules (ie. those changes that require a cache invalidation)?
Maybe it would be possible to use the list of files and folders associated to a module to automatically detect those significant changes? If no general strategy is applicable then probably this issue can be closed.

I see no clear reuse here, since handleGlobalProjectChange() is a specific trigger for a resource change listener to update all ProjectModuleFactoryDelegates in response to workspace changes. Although it's possible that non-project modules would change in response to the workspace changes, there is no direct/mandatory relationship here. I will leave it up to each module factory implementor to decide when the modules need to be invalidated and react accordingly, even if it means that in some cases they'll need their own resource change listener.
Closing.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] v3.2/v3.3 TableViewer sort performance much slower than v3.0.1

long_desc.thetext: If this turns out to be SWT, please move this bug back to us.
Can you please upload the test case as an attachment? Thanks.

Created an attachment (id=53866) Testcase to demonstrate problem
Testcase (plug-in project) which demonstrates the problem
Just double-checking: Platform is Windows XP?

(In reply to comment #4) > Just double-checking: Platform is Windows XP?
Yes, results above were on Windows XP.
Have just done a quick test on a Linux platform and the performance is still worse between 3.0.1 and 3.3 (Build id I20061219-1300) to a similar proportion. Looks like sort is roughly 500 in 3.0.1 and 1000 in 3.3.

It appears that the change that caused this was clearing of all images (in all columns) rather than just the first, before setting the images from the label provider. The decorating label providers rely on the images and the text being cleared.
We can probably fix this by using Table.clear(int) instead (confirmed by a quick hack in AbstractTableViewer), but I'll have to verify that this does not break the SWT.VIRTUAL case.
To do this in a way that does not introduce new API, we'll have to add a package-private method doResetItem(int, Item) to AbstractTableViewer. If other subclasses of AbstractTableViewer can optimize this case as well, we can expose the method as API in 3.4. Adding Chris Gross to let him know about this.
Note that the same problem might be present for trees with many columns. I'm pretty maxed out, but if deemed important enough, I could look at that case too.
Oh, I forgot to mention - we already had an API for clearing an item, called doClear(int).
Gareth Jones has confirmed that this is fixed.

bug.short_desc: Support a flexible URI scheme for accessing resources in a repository

long_desc.thetext:
I think it would be a very good thing to have the resolvable path portion of this URI format (i.e. the path within the repository) look like the path portion of a regular hierarchical (e.g. file or http) URI. That is, I think it should be before, not in, the query or fragment. Also, I strongly believe this path should begin with a / to indicate that it is absolute, that you cannot .. up above it. In other words, if you want to write a reference from a resource in one CVS repository to a resource in another, you need to specify it as a complete, absolute URI.
Expressing the path within the repository as absolute is already a departure from cvs syntax, so instead of trying to make the new URI format look like cvs syntax, I would propose we use this form, instead:
cvs:pserver://anonymous@dev.eclipse.org/cvsroot/tools!/path/to/project?tag=foo
Note that this is just a reuse of the familiar jar URI syntax. I see it as conceptually quite similar, so I think it is preferable to something new and different.
My one addition is that the tag has been expressed using the usual http query syntax. My reason for suggesting this is to allow for specifying date=something or revision=something, as alternatives to tag=something.

The URI format we choose in 3.2 was more for convenience and readability. I think the path mentioned in comment 4 has an invalid scheme (i.e. the first colon identifies the scheme and needs to be followed by //).
Given the concerns mentioned, how about something like this:
cvs://anonymous@pserver!dev.eclipse.org!cvsroot!tools/path/to/project?tagName
This format encodes the connection type and root path into the authority (which seems appropriate) which allows the path to be the actual path (i.e the URI will be hierarchical instead of opaque).

Michael,
What Dave suggested is definitely valid---Dave's an expert having implemented org.eclipse.emf.common.URI based on a careful reading of the RFC so contradict him at your own risk ;-)---because it's exactly how "archive" schemes are structured. See https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=84327 for some examples. We provide special treatment for archive URIs because they do need to be interpetted as being hiearchical even though technically the are not.
That being said, I like your suggestion even better since it is a hierarchical URI instead of opaque. The basic idea is to ensure that the parsing of the URI will treat the repository location itself as the authority of the URI:
http://www.eclipse.org/emf/2.3.0/javadoc/org/eclipse/emf/common/util/URI.html#authority()
while the rest becomes part of the path. Your suggestion has the added benefit that it wouldn't be confused for a URI that's accessing the contents of an actual archive.
Perhaps this form is closer to the "standard form" for the respository part and it's probably good to used the "standard" key/value pair aspect for the query string.
cvs://:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:!cvsroot!tools/path/to/project?tag=foo
I.e., I don't think we need to replace ":" with "!" on the "/"...

Yes, I see now. I was looking at the parsing schemes for particular interpretations of the URI and not the general form. I was trying to avoid my own parsing if possible but I see your point. With your proposal, the authority would be opaque (i.e. we couldn't use the user info, host or port get methods on URI) and everything else would match the formats of the java.net.URI (i.e. we could use getPath and interpret the query).

I have released the first round of changes for this to head. The URI is as specified in comment 3 with the following exception. I created separate query tags for the different tag types (i.e. you can put version=v1 or branch=b1 or revision=1.5).
However, I don't think this will give you everything that you want. The problem is that when you open an editor, the editor is on a particular file revision but the tag that was used to determine what revision to show is not included (if you remember I mentioned that you could adapt the editor input to IFileRevision). Hence, the URI of the file revision could be something like this for example:
cvs://:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:!cvsroot!tools/path/to/file.txt?revision=1.5
The problem here is that, although you can get the path to other files from this, you would not know what revisions you required (i.e. in CVS, the file revision has no link to the branch or version a file belongs to). One possible solution is to include the tag in the file revision so the provided URI would be something like this:
cvs://:pserver:anonymous@dev.eclipse.org:!cvsroot!tools/path/to/file.txt?branch=HEAD,revision=1.5
The problem then becomes that the client needs to interpret the query to know that the revision portion should be removed when looking for other files and this requires CVS specific knowledge. I guess another option would be to provide two URIs off of IFileRevision: the first being the exact revision and the second being for the branch or version (i.e. line of descent). We also need to keep in mind that the branch or version may not be known (for instance, if the file was opened from the history view, it would not be associated with a branch or version but if it was opened from the repo view, it would). The IFileRevision does have a getTags method that returns all the tags so the user could be prompted to pick a tag if needed.

Michael,
I've been working on https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=164597 which provides more flexible control (no need to specialize the resource implementation) over how URIs are deresolved during save and resolved during load. This type of thing will probably be very useful for preserving some of the query string information of the referencing resource. Since the serialized references won't themselves indicate which version they reference (nor would we want that!) there's only so much we can do. So we'd probably want, as you say, to preserve the branch= value, but certainly not the revision= value.
I'll need to play with this now to understand how to exploit it effectively (which means I'll need to find some time). Thanks so much for helping with this effort!

I've given this some thought and, at this point, I don't think it is practical to provide more Team API for this. I think the best place to start would be to have URI resolvers that are specific to particular repository providers and see how that works out. From this, we should get a better feel for the specific requirements and can then investigate providing a general API.
I'm marking this issue fixed since we did surface the API required to convert between a URI and a remote resource. Please log additional enhancement requests if you encounter issues that require additional capabilities.

bug.short_desc: PDOM integration into CPPSemantics.postResolution

long_desc.thetext:
The PDOM integration in the binding resolution mechanism does not seem to be entirely correct. Specifically, in CPPSemantics.postResolution:
1) the index should be consulted when the binding is null, but not when we have a problem binding. 2) The check that creates a SEMANTIC_INVALID_TYPE problem should be done on the pdom binding as well. 3) The pdom binding should likely also be considered for the call to addDefinition.
I will attach a patch with what I mean. These changes are not insignificant and should be considered and tested.
Created an attachment (id=53821) proposed changes
Due to the fix for bug 164619 there should not be a need to do this. If you disagree, please reopen the bug.

bug.short_desc: ICPPASTTemplateId should have isTemplateQualified

long_desc.thetext:
The template keyword is not really a part of the name. The expected result here for this name would be an ICPPASTQualifiedName containing 2 sub-names: T which is a normal IASTName and adjust which is a ICPPASTTemplateId (name = adjust, argument = 100)
Marking this as invalid, please reopen if I have misunderstood you.

The presence of the template keyword here only serves to indicate that the expression should be parsed as a template-id instead of a regular name followed by less than sign. Once it is parsed as a template-id, the template keyword here has no affect on sematic resolution.
Specifically, this is all the spec has to say about it (ISO 1998): 14.1-4 "When the name of a member template specialization appears after . or -> in a postfix-expression, or after nested-name-specifier in a qualified-id, and the postfix-expression or qualified-id explicitly depends on a template-parameter, the member template name must be prefixed by the keyword template. Otherwise the name is assumed to name a non-template."
In this case, we are correcly parsing the name as a template-id, the qualified name contains a correct ICPPASTTemplateId as its second nested name. I believe this information is implicit in the context of the ICPPASTTemplateId. However, if you want this explicitly in the interface it would not go on the qualified name, it would be something like ICPPASTTemplateId.isTemplateQualified.
Created an attachment (id=53977) Implementation for the suggested method
I can get all the information from the context. Could someone with the "bugzilla-power" close this bug?

(In reply to comment #5) > I can get all the information from the context. Could someone with the > "bugzilla-power" close this bug?
Marking as wontfix.

bug.short_desc: Test navigator doesn't show regular JUnits that are not under a source folder

long_desc.thetext:
1) Create a Java project without a source folder 2) Create a regular JUnit under the Java project 3) Switch to the test perspective and click the "logical" toolbar item of the test navigator

bug.short_desc: [DiagramEditor] Create ResourceSetDiagramDocumentProvider class

long_desc.thetext:
Currently used FileDiagramDocumentProvider works incorrectly with real diagrams (notation and semantic model loaded from tge different EMF resources). In particular:
- diagram editor will be marked as dirty only if diagram EMF Resource was modified - all *Rules returned by this provider wraps only diagram resources -> the rest of the loaded resources can not be correctly saved, etc. (https://bugs.eclipse.org/bugs/show_bug.cgi?id=112825) - FileDiagramDocumentProvider listens only for diagram file changes in eclipse Resources subsystem -> the rest of the loaded EMF resources (semantic model files) could be changed on disk without corresponding processing (refresh) in diagram editor - eclipse Resource renaming processed only for diagram file - save action saves only diagram resource
I suggest to create separate class ResourceSetDiagramDocumentProvider based on EMF ResourceSet internally and implementing all these requirements.
Created an attachment (id=53827) Implementation of the corresponding DocumentProvider

Attached patch conteins required DocumentProvider implementstion. Currently tooling re-generate this implementation for each diagram. Once this patch will be commited, generated code will be able to use it.

Created an attachment (id=59606) More correct version created
This version works without any *EditorInputProxies + with EMF URIEditorInput
(From update of attachment 53827) New version created
Without this class generator always produce a lot of identical code.
Created an attachment (id=59772) Removing ResourceSetModificationListener in ResourceSetInfo.dispose()
*** Bug 174501 has been marked as a duplicate of this bug. ***
Created an attachment (id=64111) Tacking care of touch events

Now GMF is generating RCP-compatible code. Different DocumentProvider should be used in this mode. Nevertheless, huge part of ResourceSetDiagramDocumentProvider could be reused in RCP mode too. So, to my understanding the best solution would be to split ResourceSetDiagramDocumentProvider on at least 2 classes RCPDiagramDocumentProvider and IDEDiagramDocumentProvider. First one will support URIEditorInput, second will subclass RCPDiagramDocumentProvider and support FileEditorInput in addition.
What do you think of this? I can provide you with modified patch if you agree it make sense and point me to the appropriate plugin for RCPDiagramDocumentProvider (org.eclipse.gmf.runtime.diagram.ui.resources.editor ?).
Any news about comment #10?

bug.short_desc: [CommonNavigator] Problem setting initial selection to a nested element

long_desc.thetext:
Build found in: 3.2.1 Release Build
Other configuration: WTP (WST + JST) 1.5.2 Release Build
Steps to reproduce: I will be attaching code that demonstrates the problem, with steps to follow.
Description of the problem: I have a wizard that uses the CommonNavigator to allow the user to select an element in the workspace, to perform some cool function on it. I would like to initialize the selection in the viewer to whatever element is currently selected in the Project Explorer or Package Explorer, but it doesn't always work. After constructing the navigator viewer and setting its input, I try to set the selection, but it has no effect whenever the selection is a Java element (using the element, itself, as a selection, rather than the Project Explorer's ITreeSelection).
The problem is, that for an element which has not yet been shown in the viewer, selecting it requires first constructing all of the TreeItem widgets in its path from the root, then selecting its TreeItem. This can only be done by computing the path from the root, which requires walking up the parent lineage of the object (in my case, a Java class or method) to be selected. At every step, to find the parent of an element in the path, the NavigatorContentService consults all providers that can provide the element as the child of another, asking what is the parent. This can result in a parent being calculated that would not actually appear in the given context if the tree were expanded from top to bottom. Once such a foreign element enters into the tree-path of the element (Java class or method) to be selected, expanding the tree from the root to reveal it and select its widget finds that the foreign element doesn't exist after all and gives up.
In a particular case of a Java method, the process is as follows: - parent of JavaMethod is SourceType [from JDT] - parent of SourceType is CompilationUnit [from JDT] - parent of CompilationUnit is PackageFragment [from JDT] - parent of PackageFragment is PackageFragmentRoot [from JDT] - parent of PackageFragmentRoot is CompressedJavaProject [from WTP JST] -- this is the problem (*) - parent of CompressedJavaProject is JavaProject [from JDT]
At this point, we have an element (JavaProject) that has a TreeItem already. This TreeItem is then asked to create its children, which *do not* include a TreeItem for the CompressedJavaProject (because it doesn't appear in this context). Finding a TreeItem for this element, then, fails and no selection is set.
An initial work-around that I tried was to set the selection twice. This works for this specific scenario, because the first attempt accomplished the creation of the TreeItem for the PackageFragmentRoot. A second look-up of the parent hierarchy of the JavaMethod only has to go this far, then, to find an existing TreeItem, so the rest of the items in its lineage can be created. Of course, depending on the number of content providers and the number of places in the tree where they insert content, twice may not always be enough.
I am not sure of whether this is a bug in the NavigatorContentService (not doing enough checking that the parent it finds really is in the tree) or a bug in the JST content provider (providing a parent when it really shouldn't)? Perhaps it is the latter, because the project in question is just a plain Java project, but I did see somewhere while debugging that the JST content provider returned no parent because it detected that its context didn't apply.

Created an attachment (id=53828) Test Case for the bug
A zipped up Project providing a reproducible test case.
To reproduce the problem, unzip the attached project into your workspace and follow these steps:
1. Launch a run-time workbench. Be sure that WTP 1.5.2 is in your config. 2. Create a plain Java project. In this project, create a package and a class in the package. Add a method to the class. 3. In the Project Explorer (or Package Explorer), select the method created in step 2. 4. Right-click, select "CommonNavigator Bug -> Show in Common Navigator" context menu action. 5. Observe that a dialog showing the common-navigator contents for the workspace appears, but the method is not selected. 6. Shut down your run-time workbench. 7. Uncomment the statement indicated in the example.bug.navigator.dialogs.CommonNavigatorDialog.createDialogArea() method. 8. Try steps 1 through 5 again, and observe that now the initial selection is correct in the dialog.

bug.short_desc: Remove garbage when imported signed plug-ins

long_desc.thetext:
When importing signed JARd plug-ins WITH source, we should remove all the signing-related garbage from the manifest.mf upon importing.
This can simply be done by reading the signed manifest and then regurgitating the keys/values and saving them
Note that the problem does not occur when importing plug-ins as binary because we already write the manifest.mf file upon importing in that mode to modify the Bundle-Classpath header. So we should do the same here wrt reading/writing the manifest, except that we don't have to modify the Bundle-Classpath header in this case.

Will be available in 3.3M4

bug.short_desc: Autobuild not resuming after interruption by other job

long_desc.thetext:
Build: 3.3 M3
From Brian S in an email:
I have seen certain situations where making a change in the workspace (e.g. saving a file) does not appear to cause an auto build to occur. I did some debugging and I believe the build is getting invoked, but then it is being cancelled because there are pending jobs that are not system jobs. To test this out, I set a breakpoint in the method AutoBuildJob::isInterrupted() and then I made a change to a Java file and saved the file. When the breakpoint was hit, I modified the interrupted field so that the value was true and allowed the code to run again. It appears that the Auto Build is cancelled to allow non-system jobs to complete first, but the auto-build is never rescheduled and pressing Ctrl+B in the workspace has no effect. The only way to get the builder to run is to make another change to the file so that auto build is run again. I have also been able to recreate the case where the isBlocking() method returns true in the JobManager, which sets the interrupted field to true in the AutoBuildJob as well.
Is the AutoBuildJob relying on the fact that the non-system jobs will invoke a build or modify a resource so that auto build is rescheduled? Do you think that the existing AutoBuildJob code should be automatically rescheduling the AutoBuildJob?

My response:
I think you're right. The build job is relying on the assumption that the job interrupting it will either be a WorkspaceJob or will involve at least one workspace operation. AutoBuildJob.canceled records that the build was canceled so that next time a workspace operation ends, even if it's a no-op WorkspaceRunnable, the build will get started. I believe this means if autobuild is interrupted by a job with a resource scheduling rule that never runs a workspace operation, then autobuild won't run automatically when the job completes.

Created an attachment (id=53840) Fix
Curiously this correct behaviour was originally in autobuild job, but then I removed it in revision 1.24 along with some apparently unrelated changes. I guess I must have convinced myself that it wasn't necessary to eagerly reschedule the autobuild job on interrupt because the interrupting job would make that happen when it finished running.

Created an attachment (id=53841) Test case
Also attaching the automated test that verifies the fix.
Fix released.

I should document an easy workaround for those on earlier releases: This problem only occurs if a job has a resource scheduling rule, but never actually runs any workspace operation. The recommended workaround is to subclass WorkspaceJob instead of Job. WorkspaceJob wraps the job's run method within a workspace operation. This will cause autobuild to be correctly rescheduled when it completes.

John, any possibility of getting this into 3.2.2?
It's causing trouble for us due to WTP validators. Users import projects from archives; the projects build partially and then abort midway through the build because of conflicts with validation jobs that were triggered from resource listeners; but the validators don't affect the workspace so there's no rebuild. Then, five minutes later, shazam, the build happens again and a bunch of new errors appear or go away.
Agree, the failure case here is pretty bad. I've opened bug 167178 to track backporting this into 3.2.x.

Created an attachment (id=53830) patch to reproduce
I'll try to extract a compiler test.
It seems that this is done only by javac >= 1.5. javac 1.4.2 behaves like we do (i.e. NPE).

We have the right behavior. If target is >= 1.4, then this$0 is initialized before the super call. If target is < 1.4 (and I guess you have target 1.2), then this$0 is initialized after the super call and you end up with the NPE. So if you don't want to use your workaround, you should change your source/target levels.

Added regression test org.eclipse.jdt.core.tests.compiler.regression.InnerEmulationTest#test130.
Closing as INVALID.

I'll try to find the reference for this particular problem. The solution is to use source 1.4 and target 1.4. JDT/UI has 1.4 as the execution environment. So you are fine to change the defaults.
Philippe, do you remember from where this is coming from?

We do the right thing. Basically, the new codegen guarantees initialization of enclosing instance slot prior to invoking super constructor, which is intended in your case. However, this codegen is only allowed on 1.4VMs, since before that it would break bytecode verification.
This is a known language limitation for pre-1.4 targets.

> This is a known language limitation for pre-1.4 targets.
Here's the Javac bug: http://bugs.sun.com/bugdatabase/view_bug.do?bug_id=4030374

bug.short_desc: Examples not tagged as project

long_desc.thetext:
The EMFT Transaction example wizard should be tagged as "project" so it appears when user selects "New > Project".
Should update the extension org.eclipse.ui.newWizards and add:
project="true"
NOTE: Query and Validation have the same issue
Committed the fix to HEAD (1.1).

bug.short_desc: [Commands] org.eclipse.ui.commandImages API and documentation error

long_desc.thetext:
At the bottom of the page describing
Identifier: org.eclipse.ui.commandImages
Since: 3.2
We read:
API Information: Within the workbench, it is possible to get images for commands using the org.eclipse.ui.handlers.ICommandImageService interface. This interface can be retrieved from supporting workbench objects, such as IWorkbench itself. To retrieve the service, you would make a call like IWorkbench.getAdapter(ICommandImageService.class).
But if you follow this advice you find :
Discouraged access: The type ICommandImageService is not accessible due to restriction on required library C:\atf\eclipse\plugins\org.eclipse.ui.workbench_3.2.0.I20060605-1400.jar
Also the call syntax is incorrect as getAdapter is not a static member of IWorkbench.
Looks like the API was made provisional but the extension point was left in place.

Hello Paul,
I fully migrated to the new menu & command API with 3.3 However I feel that commandImages is heavily broken. Its defined hover & disabled images will be neither used for menu or toolbar contributions. I always have to declare them on each menu and toolbar item over and over again. I thought commandImages extension was created to make this process easier and more centralized? Now, reading this bug here gives me the impression the commandImages is not even official API and should not be used anyway? Whats the status of the extension and is there any other centralized way to declare command images for the UI?
Thanks, Phil

(In reply to comment #3) > Hello Paul, > > I fully migrated to the new menu & command API with 3.3 > However I feel that commandImages is heavily broken. Its defined hover & > disabled images will be neither used for menu or toolbar contributions. I > always have to declare them on each menu and toolbar item over and over again.
If that is the case please open bug with your small example plugin (command + command images + place them in a toolbar).
> I thought commandImages extension was created to make this process easier and > more centralized?
It should.
> Now, reading this bug here gives me the impression the commandImages is not > even official API and should not be used anyway? Whats the status of the > extension and is there any other centralized way to declare command images for > the UI?
commandImages is not yet API, although it should work in at least 2 places. Your command images should show up in the keybinding page and they should show up in toolbars and menus contributed through the org.eclipse.ui.menus extension point. But that's the reason it is not yet API, it hasn't been fully implemented.
PW

(In reply to comment #5) > I guess the compile errors in HEAD of ICommandImageService (compiling with > I20071017-1638) could explain this. The constants in the interface are all > null: >
That would do it, although it's been that way since day 1 (Feb 06).
PW

(In reply to comment #5) > Should probably be: > public static final int TYPE_DEFAULT = CommandImageManager.TYPE_DEFAULT; >
I've released this fix to HEAD PW

PW

This is much closer.

PW

bug.short_desc: Index: macro redefinitions are not stored

long_desc.thetext:
In the code below, only one of the macro definitions is stored in the index.
#define macroXXX 1 #undef macroXXX #define macroXXX 2
adding redefinition to the index as well. fixed in 4.0 > 20061115.
